Title: Learning health systems
Source: IEEE Int. Conf. Healthc. Inf., ICHI
Abstract: © 2019 IEEE.This tutorial will focus on Learning Health Systems (LHS) as a data-driven approach to quality improvement in complex healthcare organisations. The tutorial will present the concept of the learning health system and give participants an opportunity to consider a range of typical problems involved in managing healthcare organisations and to reflect on the different forms of data and analytical methods that can be used to identify improvements. These will be discussed in the context of recent LHS projects from the UK such as Connected Health Cities. The tutorial leads will present examples of approaches to identify outliers, to predicting demand, to measuring flow, and to stratifying populations. They will illustrate how initiatives to collect, share and link electronic health data support can support these aims. Finally the tutorial will explore the practical challenges involves in trying to move from analysis to impact. Intended Audience The tutorial is aimed at a those interested in learning about the challenges faced in implementing learning health systems, with a focus on practical problems associated with access to data, data quality, choice of analytical approach and implementing change. Short Biography-Georgina Moulton is a Professor of Bio-Health Informatics Education at The University of Manchester, UK. She is an Associate Director of Training at the national institute, Health Data Research in the UK (HDR UK) as well as being Director of Workforce Development and Training for the Department of Health funded programme, Connected Health Cities. She leads the education and training in health informatics and health data science at her host institution. Paul Taylor is a Professor of Health Informatics at University College London, author of 'From Patient Data to Medical Knowledge' and the Deputy Director of the Institute of Health Informatics at UCL. He works closely with partners in local NHS Foundation Trusts and with industry on projects aimed at improving clinical processes.
